intro: Silene rhiphaena, commonly known as the mountain catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or open habitats, often at elevations above 1,000 meters. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. Silene rhiphaena is known for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain herbivorous insects.
